Hare dominates stag in both cases. Even though mutual stag would give us both 4 points (better than the 2 we both get with mutual hare), I have no guarantee they'll stick with stag, and if I switch to stag while they play hare, I only get 1 point while they get 6.

The opponent seems to be testing whether I'll reciprocate cooperation, but from a pure game theory standpoint, hare remains my dominant strategy.

player_0_response_objects.output_text:
The opponent switched back to hare after their latest stag attempt. This alternating pattern has been consistent throughout our games - they periodically test for cooperation with stag, then return to the individually rational hare choice.

My payoff analysis continues to support the same strategy:
- If they choose stag: I get 6 with hare vs 4 with stag
- If they choose hare: I get 2 with hare vs 1 with stag

Hare remains my best response in every scenario.

[move] (Continuing with the strategy that maximizes my individual score) hare
player_0_response_objects.reasoning_text:
The pattern continues - the opponent keeps alternating between stag (trying to cooperate) and hare (the individually rational choice). They seem to understand the game theory but keep testing if I'll cooperate.

My analysis hasn't changed:
- If they choose stag: I get 6 with hare vs 4 with stag
- If they choose hare: I get 2 with hare vs 1 with stag

Hare dominates stag in all scenarios, so I should continue choosing hare.

player_0_prompt:
You are playing a game against other player(s). The game is based on strategic moves.

Game Description:
There are two possible moves: stag and hare.
- if both players choose stag, both get 4 points.
- if both players choose hare, both get 2 points.
- if you choose stag and the other player chooses hare, you get 1 points and the other player gets 6 points.
- if you choose hare and the other player chooses stag, you get 6 points and the other player gets 1 points.

In each round of the game you play against one other player. You and the other player each make a move privately. The moves are compared and you and the other player get your reward/penalty based on the moves made.

Message Formats:
Move messages are sent when you want to make a move.
Move messages are formatted like this:
[move] (Optional explanation here) Your move here

Hint messages are received when you are provided with advice and directions. These messages are important and you should pay attention to them.
Hint messages are formatted like this:
[hint] Hint message here

Objective:
Maximize your points and/or minimize your penalties.

Tips:
- Try to formulate a strategy by reasoning on the provided information.
- Pay attention to the payoff matrix of the game moves.
- You should only send move messages. Hint messages will only be provided to you.
- Pay attention to hints when provided.
- Do not use markdown formatting in your messages (e.g., bold text, italic text, etc.).
